title: Case Study: Chronic Lateral Epicondylitis (Tennis Elbow) in an Amateur Golfer
clinical_history: Mr. Thomas Jenkins is a 42-year-old right-handed investment banker and recreational golfer presenting with a 6-week history of progressive pain and tenderness localized over the lateral aspect of his right elbow. The onset was insidious, noticed initially after a weekend tournament where he played 27 holes on consecutive days. Since then, he reports persistent aching and occasional sharp pain, particularly with gripping his golf club, shaking hands, or lifting objects such as a coffee mug. He denies any preceding trauma, swelling, or numbness. Mr. Jenkins continues to play golf weekly, trying to 'play through the pain', but notes increasing difficulty and decreased performance due to discomfort.

nprs.affected_area: lateral right elbow (common extensor tendon at lateral epicondyle)

aggrevating_factors: Gripping or lifting activities (e.g., golf swing, carrying a heavy briefcase, turning a doorknob), resisted wrist extension, and direct palpation over the lateral epicondyle.
picture: [Image: Person pointing to the lateral aspect of the right elbow]
easing_factors: Rest from aggravating activities, application of ice, over-the-counter NSAIDs (ibuprofen), and use of a counterforce brace.
past_history: No previous history of elbow or upper limb injuries. Generally healthy with no prior musculoskeletal issues.
medications: Ibuprofen 400 mg as needed for elbow pain (no more than 2 times daily).
personal_history: Non-smoker, occasional alcohol use (1-2 drinks/week), exercises regularly (golf, light gym work). Lives with spouse and two teenage children. High work stress due to professional responsibilities but finds golf relaxing.
imaging: No imaging performed to date. Clinical diagnosis based on history and examination.
